text: thank you Sam um yeah so yes McLaren fan uh McLaren
tragic have been for a while hence the uh McLaren's on my wall behind me and
yes I was celebrating a little bit yesterday so uh thank you for that um it's great to be back at uh
conferences um even if virtually um and where else can you do a conference and be in your slippers uh
it's pretty comfortable here um I will also though just apologize in
advance that I do have landscapers in um they are doing stuff with concrete they do have noisy Machinery they're all at
the back of the house at the moment so hopefully you won't hear a thing but if you do my apologies in advance
so Sam said I'm uh CTO at marketplacer we are a software company based here in
Melbourne and I've been at marketplacer for five years now
so I started out when it was a very different business from what it is today
so back when I started uh it was very much a startup and the business was
really focused on running marketplaces and a lot of people in the business that
was what they were doing they were working for those Marketplace businesses so Marketplace of a software company at
that point was 12 Engineers four designers uh One support person and that
was it um and we also had Finance so shared with some of those businesses and also
we had a sales team as well so the sales team was one person just
just to clarify so when I say team that might be making it seem a little more Grand than it actually was
but if you fast forward to today then um a lot has changed so the product and Technology team which I'm part of we're
over 50 people so we've we've hired people to do testing and product managers and user researchers and more
importantly we've got customers as well um which is really exciting and they're
paying customers and what we did over the years was that we uh we had you know
a few goals at finding the right customer segment and now we've found really good traction with Enterprise
customers and the thing about uh Enterprise customers and large customers in general
is that they do have you know changing expectations of us as a software
provider than what we had in the early days so what I'm talking about today is what that's meant for us as a product
delivery organization foreign ER software developer by background so
I've worked across small medium businesses in the UK in in Asia and here
in Australia but before I joined marketplaces so immediately before I spent a couple of years working for
pretty big businesses so businesses with thousands of employees
so I do understand a little bit about the mindset of big Enterprise and how things get done and what works well for
a smaller business doesn't necessarily work well for a large Enterprise
um so when I came back to a much smaller business again it was a bit of a reset and a bit of a mental kind of uh change
to think about how a small business operates one of the things I really
enjoyed was the ability to make decisions again you know when you're in
a much larger business you've got lots of people you need to talk with you've got meetings and hierarchy and decisions
can take quite a long time it did take a little bit of time to reset that muscle
memory um so a few weeks of you know oh who should I speak to about getting approval
for this or can I do that and you know eventually I kind of I broke the habit
of not having to ratify every decision with a cast of thousands and I started
um you know moving fast again um and that's really a lot about what a startup is is about
um you know it is it is liberating to be back in the world where you can uh where you can move fast and break things uh
that famous motto which Mark Zuckerberg used around Facebook
um obviously we don't want to break things deliberately but certainly moving fast having the pace having the agility
is really important so when you're a starter that's fairly
easy because you all fit in one room you know you hear everything that's going on
um you hear all the conversations you know that you have to iterate on your business model on your customer Market
fit on your technology in order to actually be able to um to survive before
the money Runs Out so with the startup that comes very naturally although at this point I
probably should admit that we weren't traditionally kind of a startup we marketplacer had actually grown out of a
business called bike exchange which was and is a very successful Marketplace for
buying and selling bikes so bike exchange had been around at this
point for about eight or nine years so the software we were working on uh had
been around for that time as well so although the team were working on this
platform and evolving it it did have a Heritage um that's paid but kindly that's how you
talk about the Legacy software it's got Heritage and but it was pretty well architected in general it uh it had good
unit test coverage it had a good deployment Pipeline and in general the team were fairly comfortable working on
it the other thing which set us apart from a real kind of day one startup was that
we had a revenue stream we had customers people using the platform but also unusually those customers were in the
same office as us so if we wanted to get feedback from our customers around how a
change landed uh we could just wander over to their desk and ask them or more
likely they would tell you when you were on your way back from a meeting to your desk or to the break room or wherever
you happen to be so you'd certainly know about the things that were happening so the marketplace for today however is
quite different from the marketplace then so we've grown significantly
um so we've had investment from a number of big organizations so Salesforce Ventures from Woolworths investment arm
um and we've also grown in terms of the number of people marketplaces actually now separated out from the businesses
which run on the platform so it's just purely a software company it's had that investment we're about 130 people now
across Australia and and the USA we work with one of the 10 largest
businesses in Australia we've got five more ASX 200 customers
um and what we found is that what worked then when we were in South Melbourne and all in the same room doesn't necessarily
translate now but what we do want to do is retain that agility the ability to
move quickly but also not to break things so that's what I'm going to talk a
little about today um so first of all I wanted to go through challenges so these are the things which
we deal with day to day and things which have changed for us over the years and
then I'll talk through a little bit about our values and the things that we've have enabled us to meet those
challenges so the first thing I wanted to touch on was uh security so this is this is a big
one um and and you know a lot of change has happened in this space not to say that we were insecure before but that our
Focus has changed so back in the day we had good processes around the security
of our platform um so secure engineering and making sure that dependencies are updated and we
were getting pen tests done things like that but what we didn't have was a larger organizational view on
information security and as you may know about information security usually one of the weakest
links is people and people doing things probably inadvertently which put the
security of information at risk so what we needed to do was put in a more formal
information security program and process management system to make sure that we
were confident that the information we hold whether that's our information or information on behalf of our customers
is kept secure I'm pleased to say that we've recently
uh well I don't have the certificate in hand I wish I did and I could show it to you but we've been certified to ISO
27001 which is an international standard around information security
now the thing about that process is that for us it was a nine month project so we
started that in January of this year and uh we've just received the notification that the the audit's been successful and
and we'll be getting that certificate um but also that it's not just a
technical change um it goes across the entire business and it requires a lot of change from
people who this may not be for them the most important thing and the most the biggest priority for them so being able
to get people to change Behavior change processes change practices it was a really big job it can take 12
months or more for organizations to go through this so I'm pretty pleased that we managed to do it in just nine months
um and it the way we did that was twofold so one was we didn't just have one person whose job it was and said
you're the person who does this go ahead and do it we brought together a coalition of people with different
skills from across the business and invested all of them in that so that was part of it the other was
having a common goal and a goal which spoke to everybody because it's not as I say it's not just a technical change
sure it helps us in terms of our technology development but it's also a big win for our customers so being able
to talk about why this is important for the whole organization and not just one group was really important in being able
to get that change done but the reason we chose ISO 27001 was
because it's not prescriptive as a standard so it's got lots of controlled objectives in there and things to me but
it doesn't tell you how to meet those objectives the actual policies and procedures and so on that you put in
place are defined by you so we were able to customize that for our environment for our way of working and make sure
that we fit in with the way that we wanted to do things so a related topic to this is around
compliance and Regulatory Compliance with State national International
Regulators particularly around data privacy and so may 2018 the European
gdpr came into effect um required lots of things from lots of different companies
um from you know from us as well we're a small business at the time and still are the difference is though that as your
customers get bigger there's a difference between doing the right thing and proving that you're doing the right
thing so the evidence collection being able to do all of that documentation is is really really important
unfortunately there's no shortcut here it's a lot of work and my advice is really to do what we did as well with
the information security work which is bring together people from across the business and set them with a common goal
so the second kind of challenge or area of focus that we spoke about was
communication so back in the day you know when I when
I started um we moved fast and yes sometimes we broke things not intentionally of course
um and usually not actually because of regressions or bugs although they did happen usually it was because we were
releasing something new or changing something and the customers weren't expecting it so from their point of view
it was broken because it no longer worked in the way that it used to now as I said we were all in the same office at
that time so a quick yell across the room or an email would usually sort that out
back then we had one person doing support for all of our platform users whereas now we have a team of 25 people
across implementation support and customer success so if we roll out
something which customers aren't expecting then the customer teams are the ones who feel the pain and what we
don't want to do is for that to happen so the other thing to mention there is we also have customers now who have uh
contractual terms with us that we have to give them notice when major changes are happening so you know all of this
seems to be um you know against our our ability to move fast
so what we've tried to do over the years is multiple different ways of improving
our internal communication as well as our external communication so transparency has always been very
important to us uh and from my very first weeks at the organization we were
doing emails out to all of the platform users about changes that were coming
um but the problem with the emails was that nobody ever actually read them so you know we felt better about ourselves
but it didn't really help and then a few years ago we tried doing a uh an internal showcase so all of the
delivery teams would stand up and talk about what they were delivering unfortunately yeah they didn't really
enjoy that they felt like they were on show and being uh you know being judged for what they were or weren't delivering
so then we said well why don't we have the whole company do it and we'll do a whole company showcase every team every
Department we'll talk about what they're doing it was too long it wasn't you know people saying it's not relevant
um so then we tried other things so we're in in slack we have a changelog channel so all of the mergers to the
main branch they will generate a record in the changelog Channel we also
implemented a convention called conventional commits which is a way of structuring your commit messages to make
it easy and make them consistent so even though we're now across multiple repositories and not just a big monolith
each of those messages comes through and generate an automated changelog
um and that that's still going that still gives us value but we were trying other things as well so we had a weekly
slide deck which went out with every single change and again it was too long and and nobody was reading it
um so we've settled now on on where we are which is using uh a company-wide
product roadmap which we put on monday.com and um the uh what happens is every uh
Fortnight at least all of the product teams will update that everybody has access to it so they can all see what's
happening and for us at the moment this strikes the right balance of enough
information that people can look at without communication overload but the underlying point is that we've
tried different things and we've settled on something which works for us right now but we don't know if that's going to
be the right thing in the future so things will change our needs will change and uh we'll in the future we'll also
change how we do things another thing we've been uh we've put in place is what we call a launch wall so
the launch war is a weekly meeting um which all the teams attend if they're
releasing something that week and the intention of it is it's akin to a stand-up really it's it's short it's to
the point uh and any discussion gets taken offline but it's a good way for people uh to know what's happening get
the heads up around what's coming up but again we'll continue experimenting with that and we'll see how things go
the thing we've done around Communications and had to do is that we've tried to separate out deploys from
lit releases so the physical act of deploying code into a production
environment versus the commercial Act of actually that change going live to a
customer and this has become more and more important so the way we work is fairly typical is that we have a
branching strategy where all of the features and fixes get developed on a
branch and then they get merged back into the main branch and then that will deploy it out into a staging environment
smoke tests will run and then it'll it'll get into production um but what we've found is that with
having to do things like a launch wall uh maybe you're having to write up a knowledge based article put it into a
dashboard maybe through an email out um you know and those contractual commitments as well around notice
periods is that the the the lag between code being done and being released has
really blown out and rather than having code sitting in a branch rotting going
stale what we've tried to do is really push the idea that deploying the code is
fine but if you can separate that out from the actual release by using something like a feature flag that
you're able then to move on and then release that when you've actually done all of those release activities
um then the next topic I should talk about is um monitoring and monitoring and slas so
luckily for us we've generally had good monitoring um in the past unlike some other
organizations I've been part of where the first time you realize that your service is down is when a customer calls
you um so we've had generally a pretty good way of doing monitoring and alerting and
we've had systems in place for that for quite a long time what has changed her as as our customers
have got bigger is that um the expectations rise around a couple of
areas so one of those is transparency um so the transparency of how the system
is performing and and the uptime because people you know rather than just
trusting that we're doing the right thing they also want to have the visibility of of that
um also harsher penalties so you know bigger companies generally will have harsher penalties if you're if your
availability isn't there so the expectation has risen around availability per se but more around the
how we report on that the other thing that's changed is that uh there's now more expectation around
um performance as well as availability so response times latency and those
kinds of things particularly around API calls so have we done this so as I mentioned
we've had kind of good Tools in place for quite a while to manage manage this internally so we use uh you know datadog
for logging and and a lot of information goes into datadog we use synthetic
monitoring platform called wormly.com and then we use page Duty
um as managing incidents and orchestrating a lot of that together so we've had all of those tools in place
and that's how we do our internal um uh monitoring and availability and
performance uh so what we're now working on is putting that together as a dashboard that customers can use as well
using exactly the same tools um because if we get it right for ourselves getting it right for customers
is uh is a quick follow-on the next thing we've had to look at is
growth you know as the cut that's the company grows and the customers grow naturally the team grows as well and of
course that's a good thing you know it's great to have more people but it's important to note that more people
doesn't mean getting more done and it's certainly not a linear relationship
between people and amount of stuff done um and this is particularly important
you know when you think about the fact that between June 2020 and June 2021 for
our business the product and Technology team doubled and it didn't just double
it doubled at a time that our entire working lives are being thrown upside down by a global pandemic uh you know in
January 2020 all of our team technology were all based in Melbourne uh we all
had an office that we went to probably four days a week for most of us we've done some working from home we used to
have you know one day at least working from home for most people but you know fast forward to today and we've got
multiple locations across different states in Australia we're just kicking off our USA product and Technology team
as well um and we're all working from home most
of the time you know even when we're allowed back in the office you know majority of people are working remotely
so um what we've had to focus on here is a couple of things so one is onboarding
processes and being more deliberate about our onboarding processes because uh it's you know more people coming on
board you've got to have a better system for doing that and I don't just mean the logistics of you know getting a laptop
to people and accounts up and you know that's important absolutely but thinking about you know on day one
do they have a background of the business and what we're trying to achieve and how the work they're doing
fits into the bigger picture do they have someone who they can pair with to be able to get their environment set up
and be able to commit code do they understand you know the rest of the team
and again with the remote aspect now this is ever more important and it's
more than just day one now you know it's now um making sure that ongoing people who
have joined the business who have never met their colleagues in person but they actually feel connected so making
deliberate decisions around making sure that certain sessions that we do as a
team that we give people space to be able to chit chat about things making sure some of the teams do you know fun
activities and that we we support that and we recognize that you know work time
doesn't always have to be about work and the social aspect of that and making space for that and encouraging that is
really really important the other aspect of this is organizational design
and we've deliberately gone for smaller teams um a lot we'd prefer to have more
smaller teams have those fairly independent of each other and empowered so our rule of thumb is five people plus
or minus two so anywhere between three and seven people um and typically our structure has a six
month shelf life and six months for us came about because we have a natural
tension between the desire to retain stability in the teams versus changing
business needs and changing team size um so we we organize around value
streams so value stream being something that creates value for your business rather than a product or a particular
technology um so we've got six value streams at the
moment and we organize our teams around those um but what's been really important is
that those value streams change so the six streams we look at right now are not the same six streams where we're looking
at 12 months ago even because the business has evolved some streams are now less important some streams are now
more important or have have you know suddenly surfaced and so we have to sometimes restructure teams and um every
six months seems to be about the sweet spot for us
having lots of small teams though is that it becomes harder as the product
gets bigger and the team's Focus narrows it gets harder to have visibility over
the whole system and that can lead to breaking things because you make changes
and don't consider the broader system impact of that I'm not talking necessarily about changes which a
regression tests might pick up you know where you change a field here and it affects something over there more likely
it's something like adding something new and not considering how does that fit into the entire ecosystem so as an
example if we add a new um a new uh field on our checkout which
says company name okay great we've captured that on the front end where does that now go does that go to the our
portal that sellers accessed does it go to CSV exports does it go to API calls and any other multitude of places that
this data may get accessed so thinking about those broader system impacts
um and there's various ways that you can um that we've tried to get people to
have a broader system view so one is that we have a a checklist
um that is in our our issue template which gets people it's just a bit of a prompt
to think about you know does this affect these other bits of the product um another is making sure that work gets
kicked off properly so we don't just kind of go into straight into solution mode with the developer saying okay
right I'm going to write some code but trying to get the right people in the room virtually to talk about what might
happen the system impacts and so on and then the last is that launch ball as I mentioned earlier that's a bit of a
safety net because if we're picking things up at that stage probably a little bit too late but it's still
better than before but then after we've gone live um so a couple of people asking in the
chat around uh value streams so I will just outline what our value streams are
at the moment so as a Marketplace we have a number we have three main customers we deal with so there's
operators so people who run a Marketplace so think bike exchange for instance the sellers who sell the
marketplace so think of a bike shop in that instance and then the Shoppers so the people who
at the end users consumers people who are buying things off the marketplace so those are three of our value streams so
we say you know is this something which The Shopper wants the seller wants or the operator wants and then that will go
into each of those teams and then our other three value streams so one is our connections platform into other Commerce
systems so we plug into other combo systems one is technical alliances so
Integrations into payment gateways Logistics and so on and then the third is our data platform so at the moment
those are the six value streams for us and you know an example of one which has come up recently is that connections
platform um you know probably two years ago 18 months ago that wasn't something which
was necessarily a value stream for us but now it is so we've organized teams
around that you know so the last kind of challenge that I
wanted to walk through was money um you know as the team grows we get
more extensive um and you know we have to be able to account for our time
um in multiple different ways and you know we've always had to do that to some extent you know my first probably one of
my first jobs when I joined the business was to pick up the um the ATO research
and development tax incentive and part of that is measuring people's time what did you work on for how long and so on
and there was a very manual process um so it was uh you know Finance team
team leads going together through git logs through pull requests through holiday schedules and building out a
timetable of what everyone was doing at any particular time and that's laborious when you're doing it for 12 months for
15 people if you're trying to do it for 50 people it's it's almost impossible
um so what we did uh was we put together um well we bit the bullet we said we're
going to do um uh time sheeting enough of us have had a terrible experience of time
shooting that we hadn't wanted to do it you know you do the timesheet dance where you log in every week and you have to try and remember what to like work on
and it's another system and it's friction and nobody likes it um we ended up going with a system
called nicobot um and the reason was because we can meet people where they are which is in
slack so what the uh what the bot does is every morning it asks you what to do
work on yesterday you pick a couple of projects put some hours against it and Away you go and if you do the same thing
multiple days in a row it'll say to you you know you've done this a few days do
you want to just keep adding it in the future and you can say yes yes please um so that's been really helpful for us
because it's it's reduced the friction it's taken away some of that pain the patterns do timesheeting but it gives us
the accurate information at the tail end to be able to report on that for things like the ATO for account visualization
of software expenses for all sorts of reasons why that's important
so those are some of the things that have happened as we've grown bigger some of the challenges we've faced
um now I'd like to talk a little bit about the values um that we've that we we hold dear as
we've gone through this so transparency is one of those and you know we talked a little bit about this
in the communications section um when you're small it's kind of easy because you're all in the same room
pretty much you can talk to each other you can hear what's going on as you get bigger and you're no longer sitting in
the same room maybe you're virtual um it can be hard and you know one of some of the things we hear when you when
you ask teams um to share and be transparent is well you know they hold their cards close to
their chest like what if I show this thing which isn't finished yet and people don't like it or even worse what
if I show this to people and they do like it and they go and sell it before it's ready um or maybe things like um you know what
if I put a date on this initiative and then it changes because it was more complex or harder or it was bigger or
more things came up so the way that we try and Tackle this is through Trust
um and some of you will hopefully be aware of Google's work from 2015 where
they looked at the ingredients for team Effectiveness and the number one out of
those was psychological safety and that's really thinking about the team level Dynamic here we're talking about
kind of cross team and cross-department but the same holds true you know if Engineers trust that sales aren't going
to throw them under the bus by selling something that doesn't exist or if marketing trusts that a product manager
is not going to you know completely upend the delivery schedule when they've got a marketing calendar ready to go you
know that that engenders trust and allows people to be transparent
around what they're doing another aspect of transparency that we've valued um so we used to have a
fortnightly tech leads meeting and used to sit in a room and plot things and it
sounds very nefarious but we you know we were coming up with ideas for how we wanted the teams to run and at some
point we said well why are we deciding this when this affects everybody in the in the team why don't we get the rest of
the team involved and we really started to embrace like a culture of openness where those discussions we were having
about you know what should we do next how should we restructure the team what should we be doing over there we
actually did with the entire product and Technology team and um that that culture of openness meant
that we actually got rid of that fortnightly tech leads meeting because there was nothing to talk about we were already talking about it with the whole
team um it also encouraged engagement so it meant that people saw the problems we
were trying to solve and they were able to jump in and help us solve those
um and we've also continued with that as we've moved remote so uh you know obviously in slack that's where a lot of
our conversations happen these days um so we're now able to do that within
slack and the majority of our channels are open by default so all of our team
channels people can jump in see what teams are up to contribute um and so on so unless there's a good
reason to you know hide something and usually there isn't then we try and make
that open by default so that also then
comes across to one of the other things that we really value which is continuous Improvement
um and you know anyone can suggest a better way and they're encouraged to do
it as well it doesn't matter if you don't know if it's going to work or not you know you might think it will you
don't really know our attitude is very much try it you know if it doesn't work
doesn't matter we'll try something else um and Andrea will just keep trying until you know we find the right thing
or in reality that thing becomes less important so a couple of examples there I talked
earlier around our release Communications and going from the emails to the showcases to Monday and so on and
um you know that's that's something which we we know it will continue to evolve uh you know we tried something we
said well we find that there's a gap here let's try and fill that Gap let's try something when it became obvious
that maybe it wasn't working as well as it used to with change would try something new
and another example of that is as a team five years ago we used to do Retros on a
Friday and there were 15 of us and that's a still a reasonable size to do a whole team retro because the things
you're talking about are generally things which affect everybody and
there's still the kind of level of trust amongst the team to be able to be open about that but as the team got bigger
what we found was that that became less relevant because people weren't facing the same problems and so uh you you end
up with on the one hand you know the topics became very trivial because they were the only things which bound people
together and on the other hand you just had a small number of voices who were being heard all the time
by this point we'd also grown from you know two to three to however many teams and
the each of those teams was doing their own retro so actually the value of doing
the Friday retro as a whole team was was diminished but we said also you know what we enjoy it like a Friday afternoon
you get together at the end of the week it's quite nice so how can we retain that without necessarily it being a
retro so we started making it more informational and you know pushing information out rather than discussion
based and that worked but then we realized that there wasn't enough content really to do it weekly so we
moved it fortnightly and then people said oh it's a bit late you know four o'clock on a Friday I'm starting to wind
down can we make it a bit earlier in the day so it's now 11 o'clock every Fortnight you know so it's changed a lot
since its original Incarnation but what's important is we didn't just say well we like retro we'd want to keep
doing it we've always done it and therefore we should keep doing it we actually challenged ourselves to say is
this still valuable is it still useful if not let's stop doing it and let's try
and find something else to do instead and that's really key to the way that we work
so let's think about decisions um so decisions are um you know really
important to us obviously making decisions we've talked about speed and being able to make decisions quickly and
that organizational design we've put in place with small teams is really designed to be autonomous so or allow
teams to be autonomous so we do have a management structure you know there's myself some VPS and Engineering managers
and so on but our job is not to make decisions our job is to support the teams the the teams are the ones who
make the decisions because they're the ones who have the best knowledge they're the ones who are working with customers who are working with the platform doing
the technology doing whatever they do so um they you know that what we try and do
is push those decisions down um if you've seen the Spotify engineering videos you might be familiar
with the concept of alignment and autonomy um so autonomy is around the ability to
to make the changes and make the decisions and the alignment piece is really important because that's about
what are we doing so you set the big Vision you set the big goals but then the teams are responsible for figuring
out how you actually deliver on that so for us we have a big company goal we
also have for each of those value streams that were created goals for each
of those teams as well so high level Visions for each of those teams what are the things important in each of those
value streams and we're also now working on getting each of those teams to come
up with more medium term goals so that they know within themselves their
Direction and obviously that then gets ratified by you know the product and Technology leadership and we help guide
them on that but ultimately it's up to the teams to set their own goals
um the other thing in terms of decisions is around technical architecture so for
us you know we don't have an architect role it's not that architecture isn't important you know it absolutely is but
for us architecture is a function rather than a role um so we have each of those those groups
um you know those teams in the value streams and cutting across that we have working groups so we have working groups
for each of the areas that we work on back end front-end infrastructure data and so on and those working groups they
don't have a lead they have [Music] a coordinator so someone who makes sure
the meeting happens and you know make sure that the the boards are up to date and so on but nobody actually leads
those areas so we have groups of work you know those people working on those on those things and they also have slack
channels so outside of their fortnightly meetings the slack channels where people come up with those discussions and
sometimes they'll escalate them and kind of getting into the meeting if you need to have a face-to-face but otherwise things day to day get solved in those
snack channels um the autonomy also extends to how
people work and how teams work so we work on the basis of inputs and outputs
so a little bit like a function in Computing um you know you have a defined input and a defined output and that's how we set
up our teams as well so the defined inputs are the goals for those teams the
outputs are things like making sure the roadmap is updated doing communication to customers and so on but how they
actually execute on that day-to-day is up to those individual teams so we don't dictate them dictate that to them that's
just something which those teams are able to do
now of course autonomy also requires a few things in terms of supporting people
so we strongly believe in cross-functional teams that is that each
team has the range of skills in order to be able to work autonomously we actually
used to hire for people who could do everything you know and and really can't with these these full stack developers
but what we found was that as the system gets bigger that's really hard to
sustain so what we hire for is the ability for people to learn so the way we put it is that we don't
expect you to know everything but we do expect you to be willing to learn anything so you might be a ruby
specialist for instance but sometimes you might need to dabble in some typescript and you know we wouldn't just
put you on a typescript project with no support you need to be able to have the support to be able to do that
so one of our values as a business is be your best and under that we have two of
those points which is be a good human and be curious and grow and those are
really important for us when it comes to to this support topic so you've got to
be comfortable asking you know for help whether you're the newest engineer or the CTO if you don't know something be
comfortable to ask and I try and set the tone and all of the leads and everyone else they all ask questions on slack
because nobody knows everything and it's not a sign of weakness to not know something I always talk about the
15-minute rule which is um you've got to try something for 15
minutes if you don't know how to do it try doing it for 15 minutes but after 15 minutes you have to ask for help because
we don't want people just to ask for help at the first drop of a hat you've got to have a go at solving it but by
the same token if it's going to take you days to solve a thing and somebody could solve it for you in half an hour ask for
help um so the kind of opposite aspect of
that is willingness to help of course you've got to have people who want to get out there and help and you'll see this all the time on slack where people
ask questions and people will jump in with a Hangouts link and say you know let's let's work through this together
even if they don't know the answer they're willing to jump in and help people out and the reason that this
works is because we don't measure people by you know lines of code or a number of commits or whatever it might be we
measure people by impact and the impact they have and we grow we either succeed
or fail as a collective it's not about individual responsibility
so we've also encouraged this in in slack we have a shout outs Channel A lot
of these the things you see in shout outs channel are people helping you know saying thank you to person X for helping
me out with something so last couple of things I'll go through
um we really value owning your own process um so staying one step ahead so the
thing I talked about earlier with ISO 27001 that was us staying ahead of the
requirements from our customers to have that in place the other thing is around slas for instance you know we want to go
in there on the front foot for any negotiations to say this is how we operate these are our standards and you
know we want you to accept our standards where possible you know not to say that we won't negotiate with customers but
let's go in there on the front foot a couple more things so tools
um cat talked about this earlier and her in her talk um you know the importance of having the right tooling
um and for us this is twofold so one is sometimes we invest in tools at the time level so we have a number of you know
various slack Bots which assign pull requests or come up with change logs or one which books out test environments
things like that and they're things that we've said well that's you know valuable for all of us because it saves time and
energy and it's worth investing in and the other is paid software you know and and my advice would always be if you get
value out of a piece of software pay for it like I've been in organizations where people have been through tortuous
processes to avoid paying for a particular piece of software and they'll do sub-optimal processes in order to
save a few dollars and it's just not worth it um you know there are good free tools
out there of course you know the majority of our team use vs code or Vim or emacs or other free tools for their
daily work there are people who prefer paid Ides and if that's what makes them
productive and comfortable and happy it's worth paying for rather than forcing them to go to a tool just
because it's free foreign the other thing on that is around overlap for tools so we actually have
different tools in the same space so we use Trello and notion and Monday which are all very similar and we also use
lucidchart and and Miro again which have a lot of overlap and we do try and consolidate on these
but what we've found is that sometimes you know people have invested in one particular tool and then we try to get
them to migrate to another and just the the the change fatigue from that is is really massive
um so uh you know we we do try and consolidate those but we don't do it at
the expense of people uh people's productivity
so just a couple of things to uh to finish off um so stability is another big thing for
us um you know a lot of these things we're talking about are changes um so we try not to overload people with
too many changes you know we were aware that each of the changes has um cumulative effect on people
um so we do try and minimize the changes where possible or at least stage them out so they're not all happening at once
and then the other thing is around immutable teams so for us we talked about that organizational design we try
and keep them stable because if teams you can't change a team they're immutable like if you add somebody if
you take somebody away it's a new team now you've got new Dynamics you've got new people in there new things to get
used to so being really conscious about that team stability as I said balancing that with the need to change
so just to wrap up um change you know is difficult um you know you go to traditional change
models like Cottage eight stages and so on they're all focused around big organizational changes you know mergers
and Acquisitions and redundancies and those kinds of things what we're talking about here is micro changes you know
lots and lots of little changes no not to say that we won't ever do big organizational changes but for us
managing lots and lots of little changes is easier than doing one big change program
um and that continual change means that we can move fast it means hopefully we don't break things as well
